questions.text: A 19-year-old football player is brought to the emergency department by his roommate after he complained of lower extremity weakness. He initially had “tingling” of the toes, but he attributed it to an “intense practice” several days ago. The patient also reports he has not voided urine in the last 5 days. Four weeks ago, the patient had a febrile diarrheal illness that resolved after several days. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 44/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg. Physical examination reveals absent ankle and knee reflexes but intact sensation to light touch and pain. A lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following cerebrospinal fluid findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness and autonomic dysfunction (e.g. failure to void) in the setting of recent diarrheal illness. He likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), and analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would show elevated protein levels and a normal cell count.  

GBS typically presents after a preceding upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection, with Campylobacter enteritis being the most common cause. As antibodies are generated against the bacteria (or virus), there is production of cross-reactive antibodies (molecular mimicry) that attacks peripheral Schwann cells, resulting in immune-mediated segmental demyelination. Clinical features of GBS include “pins-and-needle” sensation of the extremities and bilateral ascending flaccid paralysis. Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., difficulty voiding, bradycardia, tachycardia) may also be present. Severe cases of GBS can cause paralysis of diaphragmatic muscles and eventual respiratory failure requiring intubation.    

Diagnosis involves CSF analysis, which classically shows elevated protein levels with normal cell counts. This phenomenon is termed albuminocytologic dissociation. The elevated protein is likely due to increased permeability of the blood-nerve-barrier. Further diagnostic tests can include nerve conduction studies, which will demonstrate reduced nerve conduction velocity due to demyelination. Treatment involves plasmapheresis (to remove circulating autoantibodies) as well as intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) (which interferes with activation of complement and production of cytokines).  

 

Option Analysis

✅   Protein  Glucose  Cells  175 mg/dL  45 mg/dL  3/mm3 :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Protein  Glucose  Cells  255 mg/dL 10 mg/dL 1870/mm3 (neutrophils):
Incorrect: This cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding is seen in bacterial meningitis. Bacterial meningitis is often caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, and CSF findings typically show decreased glucose (as bacteria use it for metabolism) and significantly elevated levels of neutrophils. This patient lacks typical signs of bacterial meningitis (e.g., fever, nuchal rigidity, headaches), and the bilateral, ascending paralysis is indicative of another condition. 
❌   Protein  Glucose  Cells  125 mg/dL 50 mg/dL 75/mm3 (lymphocytes):
Incorrect: Viral meningitis results in CSF lymphocytosis, as opposed to significant granulocytosis seen in bacterial meningitis. Glucose levels are typically normal. However, this patient lacks the symptoms associated with viral meningitis. 
❌   Protein  Glucose  Cells  135 mg/dL25 mg/dL 85/mm3 (lymphocytes):
Incorrect: Fungal meningitis results in CSF lymphocytosis, similar to viral meningitis, but is characterized by decreased glucose as the fungi use the glucose for metabolism. Fungal meningitis typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals and presents with a subacute onset. Bilateral ascending, flaccid paralysis as seen in this patient would be an unusual presentation of fungal meningitis. 
❌   Protein  Glucose  Cells 130 mg/dL 45 mg/dL  250/mm3 (erythrocytes and lymphocytes):
Incorrect: CSF analysis in herpes encephalitis would show lymphocytosis, as well as the presence of erythrocytes due to necrotizing and hemorrhagic brain parenchymal inflammation. Patients typically present with fever, altered mental status, and focal neurological deficits secondary to medial temporal lobe involvement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to spinning sensation and feeling unstable. This sensation started 1 month ago and since then has gotten gradually worse. She also describes constant fatigue and tingling sensation in both of her upper extremities. She states that several months ago, she went to the emergency department for an episode of intense right eye pain with movement and the loss of color vision; this gradually improved over 2 weeks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows ataxia and nystagmus. A head MRI shows multiple hyperintense periventricular and cerebellar ovoid lesions. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young woman with a history of fatigue, optic neuritis, sensory abnormalities and head MRI showing periventricular sclerotic plaques likely has multiple sclerosis (MS). The patient’s history of the gradual onset of a spinning sensation consistent with the central vertigo that can be caused by MS. From the answers above only multidirectional nystagmus is associated with central causes.  

Vertigo can be broken down into peripheral vertigo, which is due to damage to the vestibular apparatus or the vestibular nerve, and central vertigo, which is due to damage to the vestibular structures in the brainstem or cerebellum. In MS patients, sclerotic plaque formation and demyelination within the cerebellum can result in central vertigo. Central vertigo has various characteristics, and is summarized in the table below, but one major difference is the nature of the nystagmus. In central vertigo, the direction of the nystagmus is multidirectional (e.g., horizontal, torsional or rotatory, vertical), whereas in peripheral vertigo, the nystagmus can be horizontal or torsional, but not vertical.  

For completeness of the examination, the term "dizziness" should be clarified with the patient. It is a nonspecific term often used by patients to describe symptoms for which the cause can include vertigo, nonspecific "dizziness," disequilibrium, and presyncope.

Differences between central and peripheral causes of vertigo, as well as their etiologies, are described in the table below:    



Option Analysis

❌ Sudden head movements cause vertigo:
Incorrect: This sign is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.  
❌ Visual fixation suppresses the nystagmus:
Incorrect: This sign is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.  
✅ Multidirectional nystagmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Presence of deafness or tinnitus:
Incorrect: The addition to hearing loss or tinnitus is characteristic of peripheral vertigo, while this patient’s presentation and associated imaging findings are more consistent with central vertigo.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with 3 days of progressively worsening lethargy, irritability, and confusion. The child’s grandmother noticed the boy had trouble walking earlier in the day. He has no significant past medical history, but he recently returned from a camping trip 7 days ago. The grandmother is unable to provide further details. The patient’s temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a stuporous child that is arousable with sternal rub. Nuchal rigidity is absent. Ocular examination reveals intense pain with eye movements. Head MRI shows multiple lesions in the subcortical white matter, characteristic of demyelination. The patient receives proper treatment and recovers fully within a week. Which of the following is likely to be found in this patient’s history on further questioning?

choices.text: Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States
Episode of monocular blindness that spontaneously resolved
Recent contact with a child with fever, headache, and neck stiffness

questions.solution:
This child has acute-onset altered mental status and pain on extraocular movement in the setting of an MRI revealing multiple subcortical demyelinating lesions. He most likely has acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM).  

ADEM is a rare type IV (cell-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction. In this condition, T-cells are activated by myelin proteins and release cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha), which dilate blood vessels, allowing more immune cells (e.g., macrophages, B-cells) to infiltrate and damage oligodendrocytes. B-cells begin synthesizing antibodies that mark the myelin sheath proteins. Macrophages then use the antibody markers to engulf and destroy the oligodendrocytes, leading to diffuse demyelination at multiple locations throughout the brain and spinal cord.  

The underlying trigger for ADEM is unclear, but since some pathogens have proteins similar to oligodendrocytes proteins, molecular mimicry may be an underlying etiology. A variety of viral infections are associated with ADEM, including influenza, measles, mumps, rubella, and various human herpes viruses. Although vaccines were previously thought to be a trigger for ADEM, this theory has largely been disproven.  

Symptoms of ADEM have acute-onset, and usually begin 1-3 weeks after exposure to the trigger. Since ADEM is associated with systemic inflammation, most individuals have fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Eventually, demyelination breaks down communication between neurons, leading to visual problems (e.g. optic neuritis), seizures, weakness, irritability, confusion, lethargy, and even coma. The diagnosis can be made with MRI, which classically show multiple subcortical lesions.    

Option Analysis

✅ Recent upper respiratory viral infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States:
Incorrect:  Hiking in the woods of the northeastern United States would predispose patients to contracting Lyme disease from a tick bite. Untreated Lyme disease may eventually cause progressive encephalomyelitis, but this occurs much later in the disease course. Earlier stages of Lyme disease present with a characteristic bullseye rash (erythema migrans) and migratory arthralgia, which are absent in this patient’s history. 
❌ Episode of monocular blindness that spontaneously resolved:
Incorrect: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) may have optic neuritis, which can present with loss of color vision, visual blurriness, or blindness. MS can also cause pain on extraocular movements and altered mental status. However, MS typically affects individuals between 20-40 years of age and presents with periventricular lesions. In contrast, it would be unusual for MS to affect a child or present with only subcortical lesions.  
❌ Family history of demyelinating condition:
Incorrect: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary condition that results in peripheral neuropathy due to impaired Schwann cell growth and function. Patients typically present with distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy with atrophy of the calf muscles and pes cavus deformity. Acute encephalopathy, such as in this patient, is highly unlikely. 
❌ Recent contact with a child with fever, headache, and neck stiffness:
Incorrect: Meningitis can present with acute lethargy, fever, and headaches. However, this patient is missing the characteristic neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity) typically seen in meningitis. Additionally, the MRI findings suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden loss of vision in the right eye that began several hours ago. The patient has intense pain with any movement of the eye. She has no significant past medical history, but she did have an episode of reduced sensation in her legs 6 months ago. This episode resolved spontaneously after several days. On neurologic examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. There is reduced adduction of the left eye with right lateral gaze. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Physical examination reveals decreased pain and light touch perception in both legs. Mild bilateral spasticity is observed. MRI of the brain and spine is inconclusive. Further testing is likely to demonstrate which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated nonspecific clones of IgG on CSF electrophoresis
Positive rapid plasma reagin from a sample of cerebrospinal fluid
Elevated protein levels and normal cell counts in cerebrospinal fluid analysis
Genetic testing revealing increased triplet repeats on chromosome 4

questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological dysfunctions are separated in space and time (e.g., optic neuritis, sensory symptoms, bilateral spasticity), which means the symptoms manifest at different times and affect different parts of the body. These findings are highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.   

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spine is the initial diagnostic test of choice. The presence of multiple sclerotic plaques is the most common finding in MS patients. These plaques are usually located near the ventricles (periventricular). Sclerotic plaques occur due to reactive gliosis that follows demyelination episodes. As these periventricular areas of hyperintensity stretch out perpendicularly along medullary veins, they are described as Dawson fingers (Figure 1).  

In cases wherein MRI is inconclusive, a lumbar puncture with subsequent analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is indicated. Oligoclonal bands are found in up to 95% of patients with MS. Oligoclonal bands represent increased production of multiple, nonspecific clones of IgG within the central nervous system due to intrathecal inflammation. Additionally, since Th1 cells initiate the demyelinating episodes, lymphocytosis in the CSF is another common finding, but it is not specific for MS.  

Figure 1: Dawson’s fingers (some are marked with white arrows) seen on sagittal MRI  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated nonspecific clones of IgG on CSF electrophoresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Positive rapid plasma reagin from a sample of cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect:  Positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) of the CSF suggests neurosyphilis; syphilis can present similarly to MS with ataxia and loss of peripheral sensation. However, syphilis can be differentiated by recognition of earlier signs, such as a painless genital ulcer in primary syphilis and a disseminated rash involving the palms and soles in secondary syphilis.
❌ Decreased ceruloplasmin on laboratory studies:
Incorrect: This finding is present in patients with Wilson disease, in which there is impaired copper excretion and inadequate incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin, resulting in systemic copper accumulation. Patients typically present with liver disease and neurological symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, parkinsonism), as well as characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings in the periphery of the iris. 
❌ Elevated protein levels and normal cell counts in cerebrospinal fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Albuminocytologic dissociation of the CSF is present in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome. This condition typically presents after a viral gastroenteritis (e.g. preceding diarrheal episode) with bilateral ascending, flaccid paralysis.
❌ Genetic testing revealing increased triplet repeats on chromosome 4:
Incorrect: Increased number of CAG triplet repeats in the huntingtin gene located on chromosome 4 is seen in patients with Huntington disease. Since this condition has autosomal dominant inheritance, the lack of family history makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, patients with Huntington disease also have chorea, which is characterized by involuntary, irregular movements of the limbs and/or face.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to complaints of weakness and numbness in the lower extremities. The patient has sprained both ankles on multiple occasions over the past year while playing soccer due to difficulty running, which has progressively worsened. The patient has not had any recent infections or diarrhea. The patient's family lives in a new home built 3 years ago. The patient’s mother reports the patient was adopted at the age of 3, and she is unsure of his biological family’s history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Distal calf muscle atrophy is noted. There is loss of proprioception and vibratory sensation in both feet. Ankle reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. An image of the patient’s foot is shown below. This patient’s neurological dysfunction is most likely caused by which of the following?  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) is a spectrum of inherited disorders caused by mutations in genes that are expressed in peripheral nerve myelin. Most are inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, and therefore, a family history of the disorder is usually present. CMT affects the peripheral nervous system and is characterized by defective protein production in Schwann cells or the peripheral neuron’s axon. The most common form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is CMT1. CMT1 is caused by mutations in the PMP22 and MPZ genes, which encode proteins that are part of the myelin sheath.  

Individuals with CMT typically have distal lower extremity weakness, which is similar to Guillain-Barré syndrome. The difference is that CMT also causes sensory symptoms such as pain or numbness. Early physical exam findings include distal calf muscle atrophy and loss of reflexes. Motor symptoms are also common and occur due to damage to the common peroneal nerve, which can lead to foot drop. Weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the foot can result in pes cavus, as characterized by a high arching foot that does not flatten with weight bearing (seen in the image). Weakness of the back muscles can result in scoliosis.   

Diagnosis for CMT usually begins with nerve conduction studies that show a significantly decreased conduction velocity. Genetic testing is necessary to obtain a definitive diagnosis and determine which subtype of CMT the patient has.  





Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in myelin protein gene :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyalinization of endoneurial arterioles:
Incorrect: In diabetic neuropathy, there is nonenzymatic glycosylation of tissue proteins that results in hyalinization of endoneurial arterioles. This occlusion of blood supply to the nerve results in ischemic nerve damage. However, this patient has no history of diabetes mellitus.
❌ Autoreactive T-lymphocytes attacking oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: Lesions in multiple sclerosis (MS) are caused by a type IV hypersensitivity (cell-mediated reaction) in which Th1 and Th17 T cells react against oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. This patient’s condition is likely affecting the peripheral nervous system, not the central nervous system as seen in MS.
❌ Heavy metal exposure :
Incorrect: Lead poisoning in children is a serious public health issue that can result in permanent neurological dysfunction. Lead has a direct effect on neurons resulting in neurotoxicity and neuronal death. This child lives in a modern home where lead-based paints were likely not used, and he lacks other clinical features seen in children with lead poisoning, such as abdominal pain, cognitive decline, and constipation.
❌ Autoantibodies attacking peripheral nerve endoneurium  :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is seen in patients following an upper respiratory infection or gastroenteritis. Molecular mimicry results in the production of cross-reactive antibodies against myelin found on peripheral Schwann cells, resulting in endoneurial inflammation. Individuals with GBS present with a bilateral, symmetric ascending paralysis, but typically lack the sensory deficits seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressively worsening confusion and inability to walk. She lives at home with her partner, who states that over the past week the patient has had worsening memory and trouble moving the right side of her body. The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection 3 years ago but has been non-compliant with antiretroviral therapy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical examination reveals oral thrush. The patient is not oriented to time, place, or person. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hyperreflexia and upgoing plantar reflex. CD4 count is 90/mm3. MRI shows multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions. Reactivation of a pathogen from which of the following locations is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with AIDS is presenting with progressively worsening neurologic deficits and MRI showing multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions. She likely has progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to reactivation of the John Cunningham (JC) virus.   

Most adults are exposed to JC virus at some point in their lives; normally, the virus remains latent in kidney epithelial cells in immunocompetent individuals. Immunosuppression, however, triggers reactivation of the virus and infection of oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. Likewise, patients taking certain immune-toxic drugs (e.g., natalizumab, rituximab) are also at risk. Ultimately, failure of immune surveillance within the CNS allows for an uncontrolled viral replication.  

Patients with PML will develop focal and relentlessly progressive neurologic dysfunction. PML primarily involves the parietal and occipital areas of the brain, resulting in symptoms such as changes in speech and loss of vision. Other common symptoms include weakness, clumsiness due to lack of coordination, personality changes, and dementia. Imaging with CT or MRI will show multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions, suggestive of demyelination.    

Option Analysis

✅ Kidney epithelial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Trigeminal ganglion:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is a virus that remains latent in the trigeminal ganglion after primary infection. Reactivation of HSV-1 can be caused by immunosuppression, stress, or trauma. Although reactivation of HSV-1 can result in herpes simplex encephalitis, which would also present with focal neurological deficits, MRI would show hyperintense temporal lobe lesions. 
❌ Hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) can integrate itself into hepatocyte DNA, resulting in a carrier-state. Integration into regions that control cell growth and differentiation can result in dysfunction of cell cycle proteins, causing hepatocellular carcinoma. However, it is unlikely to result in neurological deficits, as seen in this patient.
❌ Sacral ganglion:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is a virus that remains latent in the sacral ganglion after primary infection. Reactivation of HSV-2 can be caused by immunosuppression, stress, or trauma, and can present as genital herpes.
❌ Myeloid progenitor cells:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), also known as human herpes virus 5, is a virus that remains latent in myeloid progenitor cells and can be reactivated in patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, post-organ transplantation). Clinical manifestations include CMV pneumonia, retinitis, and esophagitis. CMV encephalitis can also occur, which would result in impaired cognitive functioning and neurological deficits. However, symptoms would generally develop in patients with a CD4 count of 50/mm3 or less.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician due to loss of vision and pain in her right eye which began yesterday. In addition, she also feels numbness in her left hand. Last year, the patient presented with left-sided weakness. Three years ago, the patient also had an episode of severe eye pain accompanied with ataxia. Both times, the patient was successfully treated with steroids. Neuroimaging revealed well-defined areas of demyelination in the central nervous system. The physician decides that in addition to corticosteroids, he will start the patient on Natalizumab. Which of the following is a potential adverse effect of natalizumab?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple neurological deficits separated in space and time in addition to neuroimaging consistent with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. First-line treatment of multiple sclerosis is steroids during acute attacks; however, natalizumab is another approved treatment shown to have a significant benefit in patients with relapsing-remitting MS.

Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that can be used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis and Crohn's disease. In multiple sclerosis patients, natalizumab has been shown to slow the progression of symptoms and decrease the rate of relapse in patients with relapsing-remitting courses.

Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against alpha-4-integrin receptors on endothelial cells lining blood vessels. Integrins are a class of selective adhesion molecules that are involved in the chemotaxis of leukocytes to the site of inflammation. Normally, leukocytes bind the integrins and then migrate from blood vessels to the site of inflammation. By blocking the integrins, natalizumab causes anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation and inducing a proinflammatory response. In the brain, natalizumab blocks alpha4-beta1 integrins, preventing leukocytes from crossing the blood-brain barrier and entering the CNS, which is how it decreases inflammation in multiple sclerosis patients.

One of the major limitations of the use of natalizumab is the increased risk of reactivation of JC virus. JC virus is an opportunistic pathogen that resides in the oligodendrocytes in the brain. When the immune system is suppressed, such as in HIV or with natalizumab use, JC virus can get reactivated, leading to a disease known as progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is characterized by demyelination in the CNS due to the destruction of oligodendrocytes and is rapidly progressive and fatal. Therefore, patients taking natalizumab should be tested for anti-JC virus antibodies before starting treatment and continue to be tested periodically while on natalizumab, even if the initial anti-JC antibodies were negative.

Other side effects of natalizumab include headaches and nausea. In some patients, nucleated erythrocytes can appear in the peripheral blood, which has no clinical significance and usually disappear after stopping the treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome is a fatal condition that results from rapid correction of hyponatremia. It is not associated with natalizumab use.  
❌ Hepatotoxicity:
Incorrect: Natalizumab is not associated with hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Cardiotoxicity:
Incorrect: Natalizumab does not cause cardiotoxicity. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against Her2-Neu receptors in the breast and is used with breast cancer, can sometimes lead to cardiotoxicity.  
❌ Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphoma has been documented as side effects of anti-TNF antibodies, which are monoclonal antibodies that block the action of TNF. However, natalizumab is not associated with increased risk of lymphoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office due to daily headaches for the past few months. She describes the location to be all the way around her head, and she feels like her head is under a lot of pressure. She rates the pain as a 5 on a 10-point scale, and it often worsens in severity throughout the day. She works as a secretary, and she states that she has been under a lot of stress lately. Her medical history is significant for bacterial sinusitis treated with antibiotics one month ago, and family history is significant for migraines on her mother's side. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness on palpation of her posterior neck and occiput. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a bilateral, moderate intensity headache without associated symptoms, in conjunction with her recent stress at work, most likely has a tension headache.    

Tension headaches are the most common headache worldwide. The typical presentation of a tension headache includes a bilateral, mild to moderate intensity, non-throbbing headache without other associated features. The pain is often described as “pressure-like” or “band-like” and patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. The pathophysiology is uncertain, but proposed mechanisms include peripheral activation or sensitization of myofascial nociceptors. Common precipitating factors are stress and muscle tension. Acute abortive treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatories and acetaminophen, with prophylactic treatment options including behavioral therapy and tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline).  



Option Analysis

❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches manifest as unilateral excruciating periorbital pain with lacrimation and rhinorrhea. They are more common in men than women and usually are short in duration (15 minutes – 3 hours). This patient has bilateral pain of moderate-intensity, favoring the diagnosis of a tension headache.  
❌ Migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by episodic unilateral pain which is throbbing and pulsatile in quality. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity and noise sensitivity. Patients may describe an aura preceding an attack. Although this patient has a family history of migraines, the characteristics of her headache are more consistent with a tension headache.     
❌ Bacterial meningitis  :
Incorrect: Bacterial meningitis often presents with the classic triad of fever, nuchal rigidity, and a change in mental status. Tenderness over the posterior neck and occiput is most likely caused by muscle tenderness, which is characteristic of tension headaches, and the absence of the classic signs of meningitis favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Tension headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Pseudotumor cerebri :
Incorrect: Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension, IIH) commonly presents with headache, tinnitus, diplopia, visual changes, and papilledema. Risk factors include female gender, use of tetracyclines, obesity, vitamin A excess, and use of danazol. This patient’s type of headache, with an absence of risk factors or classic IIH symptoms, favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chronic sinusitis:
Incorrect: Sinusitis often presents with a mucopurulent nasal drainage, nasal obstruction, facial pain/pressure, and reduced sensation of smell. Although this patient was treated for sinusitis a month ago, her presentation with the absence of nasal symptoms favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a headache that feels “like a screwdriver” going through his right temple and eye. He says that it has lasted for approximately 1 hour thus far, and rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. He says this has happened almost every morning this week, but he cannot identify a trigger. He also describes “watering of his eyes” and difficulty seeing during these episodes. Physical examination shows ipsilateral miosis of the right eye, but the remainder of the ophthalmoscopic examination is normal. There is no tenderness of the right temporal region on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are a type of primary headache characterized by unilateral pain around the periorbital region, and they are often described to be excruciating in quality. They often occur episodically at the same time of the day (and may occur multiple times per day), with cluster headache cycles usually occurring around the same time of the year. Autonomic symptoms are often associated with cluster headaches ipsilateral to the side of the pain, and they only occur during the headache episode. These symptoms include conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Cluster headaches may also present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis). Cluster headaches more often occur in men than women. This type of headache can often be misdiagnosed, or confused with migraines, which are also typically unilateral. Since there are no confirmatory tests for cluster headaches, a detailed patient history is imperative. Headache diaries may help track headache onset, location, severity, and duration. Abortive treatment includes 100% oxygen and triptans, while verapamil can be used prophylactically.   



Option Analysis

❌ Migraine headache:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral pain that is throbbing and pulsatile in quality, usually lasting 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity or noise sensitivity. Although this patient has unilateral headache, his autonomic symptoms favor a different diagnosis.  
❌ Trigeminal neuralgia  :
Incorrect: Trigeminal neuralgia is a neuropathic disorder that typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, “shock-like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving). This patient presentation favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Cluster headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Tension headache:
Incorrect: Tension headaches are the most common cause of primary headache. It is usually bilateral and fronto-occipital in location, with a characteristic tightening or “band-like” quality of pain. Patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. Common precipitating factors are stress and increased muscle tension. This patient has unilateral headache and autonomic symptoms, which favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Temporal arteritis  :
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) typically presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue), signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., elevated ESR and CRP) and history of scalp pain/ temporal pain and jaw claudication. Also, patients are usually above the age of 50. This patient age and presentation favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to right-sided tingling and weakness, as well as a severe headache. She says she started experiencing problems with her vision two hours ago, followed by tingling in her right hand. After this, she began experiencing weakness in her right hand, which progressively extended to her right arm and face, as well as a severe, unilateral throbbing headache that is still ongoing. Her medical history is significant for migraines, but mentions that this time it “feels different.” She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows 4/5 muscle strength on the right side compared to 5/5 on the left, as well as mildly reduced sensation on the right side. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased vision and central scotoma in the right eye. Computed tomography is obtained and shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with visual disturbance, paresthesias, and progressive weakness, followed by a severe throbbing unilateral headache, most likely has a hemiplegic migraine.  

Hemiplegic migraines are a rare type of migraine headache where patients experience motor aura characterized by progressive weakness (typically unilateral) that precedes or accompanies the migraine headache. Hemiplegic migraines always have at least two types of aura present, including visual, sensory, motor, aphasic, and/or brainstem symptoms. Most commonly, weakness starts in the hand, and progresses to involve the arm and face. These symptoms are fully reversible, with most lasting at least 60 minutes. In rare cases, hemiplegia may last up to 4 weeks.    

Like other types of migraines, hemiplegic migraines are more common in women than men. Management is similar to typical migraine headaches, including abortive medications during the acute phase as well as prophylactic treatment to prevent future episodes. In severe cases, patients may require hospitalization due to fever, altered consciousness, or seizures.  

Option Analysis

❌ Transient ischemic attack :
Incorrect: Both migraines and transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) can include reversible symptoms such as weakness, paraesthesia, and visual changes, and imaging in both cases shows no abnormalities. However, the symptoms of TIA are acute, not progressive as seen in this patient. Also, patients usually have additional risk factors (e.g., hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, advanced age), unlike this young healthy woman.   
❌ Simple seizure:
Incorrect: Simple seizures may be preceded by visual or motor auras, however it is usually associated with “positive” symptoms (e.g., shaking, jerking, flashing lights, or visual distortion) rather than “negative” symptoms (e.g., weakness, paraesthesias). Additionally, the throbbing headache and history of migraine favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: The classic presentation of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is sudden onset of a severe headache, often described as the “worst headache of my life,” brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, and neck pain or stiffness. Although this patient has an acute onset of severe headache, her computed tomography shows no abnormalities, whereas SAH should show signs of hemorrhage.   
❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches manifest as unilateral excruciating periorbital pain with lacrimation and rhinorrhea. It is more common in men than women and usually is short in duration (15 minutes–3 hours). This patient has a progressive motor aura, throbbing headache, and lacks the autonomic signs seen in cluster headaches (e.g. lacrimation, rhinorrhea), which favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Migraine headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Temporal arteritis  :
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (TA) or giant cell arteritis should be considered in patients over 50 years with the following symptoms: new headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, abrupt onset of visual disturbances/transient monocular visual loss, and constitutional symptoms. This patient's young age and lack of classic TA findings favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of recurrent, pulsating headaches and transient vision changes for the past week. She initially gained relief from taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications, but they are no longer sufficient due to the worsening of her symptoms. Her current medications include the combined oral contraceptive pill and a tetracycline for acne. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2. A focused neurological examination shows papilledema during fundoscopy, and testing of visual fields reveals some peripheral constriction. Magnetic resonance imaging is obtained and shows flattening of the posterior sclera and reduced soft tissue occupying the sella turcica. The brain parenchyma and ventricles appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young patient with multiple risk factors (i.e. female gender, obesity, use of tetracyclines) presenting with headache and visual disturbance most likely has idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH, commonly called pseudotumor cerebri, typically affects women of childbearing age, with other risk factors including obesity, vitamin A excess, and use of tetracyclines and danazol.  

IIH is a disorder characterized by clinical features of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, papilledema, visual disturbances, and tinnitus. As the name implies, the cause of the increase in intracranial pressure is unclear. Lumbar puncture typically demonstrates elevated opening pressure with normal cerebrospinal fluid composition, and imaging reveals no evidence of other causes of intracranial hypertension.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocephalus ex vacuo:
Incorrect: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo, also called ex vacuo ventriculomegaly, is characterized by an increased size of cerebrospinal fluid-containing spaces due to degeneration of the brain parenchyma. It is often seen in Alzheimer disease, advanced HIV, Pick disease, and Huntington disease. This patient’s age, symptoms, and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune inflammatory condition which leads to demyelination of CNS axons (brain and spinal cord). It can present with optic neuritis, cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), pyramidal tract signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity) and spinal cord symptoms (e.g. neurogenic bladder). MRI will likely show lesions in specific white matter areas, including periventricular, juxtacortical regions, corpus callosum, infratentorial regions, and the spinal cord. This patient’s symptoms and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Normal pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a condition that commonly affects the elderly and is characterized by periodical increase in CSF pressure and expansion of the ventricles. Compression and distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata leads to the classic presentation of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (magnetic gait), and cognitive dysfunction. MRI shows enlargement of the ventricles. This patient’s age, symptoms and MRI findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Chronic migraine  :
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral pain that is throbbing and pulsatile in quality, usually lasting 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, and photosensitivity or noise sensitivity. Although this patient has some of the features of migraine headache, her physical exam and MRI findings and her vision changes favor a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a severe headache that began four hours ago. She describes the pain as pulsating and localized to the area above her left eye. She denies any nausea or vomiting. She tried an over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication at home, which provided no relief. The patient receives another first-line medication for her condition and her symptoms soon resolve. This medication works by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake from the synaptic cleft
Inhibition of calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of pulsatile, unilateral headache is consistent with a migraine. Triptans, specifically sumatriptan, are used as first-line abortive therapy for migraines after over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) have failed. Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) agonist. The drug binds to serotonin receptors in the brain, triggering vasoconstriction, inhibition of trigeminal nerve activation (thought to be the cause of migraine pain), and decreased vasoactive peptide release (reducing inflammation). It can be administered orally, subcutaneously, or intranasally, and reaches peak blood concentration in approximately 15 minutes (faster than any other migraine-specific medication). Triptans may cause adverse effects including coronary artery vasospasm, mild paresthesias, and serotonin syndrome (in combination with other 5-HT agonists). Therefore, they are contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic, cardiac, cerebrovascular, or peripheral vascular disease, uncontrolled hypertension, and in women who are pregnant.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of H1 receptors:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of antihistamines such as diphenhydramine, commonly used to treat allergies and motion sickness. It can also be used in an acute migraine attack associated with nausea and vomiting, but this patient denies these symptoms.  
❌ Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake from the synaptic cleft  :
Incorrect: This is the proposed mechanism of action of amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant which is often used in peripheral neuropathy, chronic pain, resistant depression and migraine prophylaxis. However, it is not used for migraines during the acute phase.   
❌ Activation of somatostatin receptors :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of octreotide, a somatostatin analogue that is used to treat acromegaly, gigantism, thyrotropinoma, carcinoid syndrome, and vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumors (VIPomas). It has also shown to be effective at relieving acute cluster headaches, but not migraine headaches.   
✅ Activation of serotonin receptors :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Inhibition of calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of verapamil, which is commonly used as prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches. It is not used to treat acute migraine attacks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to 2 months of episodic jaw pain. She describes sharp shooting, “shock like” pain over the left side of her jaw that typically lasts for a few seconds. She has noticed a few times that the pain has occurred while she was eating dinner, and once while she was brushing her teeth. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the first line medication for her condition. During her one month follow-up appointment, she states that her symptoms have improved significantly, but she describes feeling some dizziness and instability. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the medication being used by this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of T-type calcium channels in the thalamus
Increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening
Increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
This patient has trigeminal neuralgia, a debilitating neuropathic disorder that typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, and “shock like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving, chewing) within the affected trigeminal nerve branch distribution. It has been hypothesized that this occurs due to compression of the trigeminal nerve root by arteries or veins, leading to demyelination in this area; however, the exact pathogenesis is unclear.  

The first line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia is carbamazepine, a neuroleptic medication that works by blocking Na+ channels, thus limiting influx of sodium ions throughout the CNS. Adverse effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, dizziness and ataxia, blood dyscrasias (agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia), liver toxicity, teratogenesis (cleft lip/palate, spina bifida), cytochrome P-450 induction, SIADH, and Steven-Johnson Syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of T-type calcium channels in the thalamus  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of ethosuximide, which is used to treat absence seizures. Ethosuximide works by blocking T-type Ca2+ channels in the thalamus. Adverse side effects of ethosuximide include fatigue, GI distress, headaches, itching (and urticaria), and Steven-Johnson syndrome.   
❌ Inhibition of high-voltage calcium channels  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of gabapentin used in peripheral neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia. Side effects of gabapentin include sedation and ataxia.   
❌ Decreasing the degradation of GABA :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of vigabatrin, which is used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures in adults. Vigabatrin works by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for the degradation of GABA. Its use is now limited, as it carries a black box warning in the United States due to risk of permanent vision damage.   
✅ Inhibition of sodium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of benzodiazepines, which are used as anxiolytics and in surgical procedures. Side effects include sedation, tolerance, dependence, and respiratory depression.  
❌ Increasing the duration of chloride channel opening:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of barbiturates, which are used in anxiety, seizures, insomnia, and induction of anesthesia. Side effects include respiratory, cardiovascular, and CNS depression.   
❌ Decreasing the degradation of acetylcholine :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine, used in Alzheimer's disease. These work by inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme, which is responsible for acetylcholine degradation.  
❌ Inhibition of the phosphoinositol cascade:
Incorrect: This is thought to be the mechanism of lithium, which is used as a mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder and treats acute manic episodes. Side effects include tremor, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and teratogenesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the outpatient neurologist for a pulsatile headache that is worse in the morning. She also has experienced occasional episodes of vomiting. She has no significant past medical history, and she does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg, pulse is 68/min., and body mass index is 25 kg/m2. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. There is no neck stiffness or cranial nerve deficits. Sensation and strength are intact in all extremities. The cardiovascular, pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. After appropriate workup, the patient is diagnosed with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. She is started on a medication that inhibits carbonic anhydrase. Which of the following laboratory findings best characterizes the adverse effects of this medication?
questions.solution:
The patient was prescribed a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI) for management of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.    

In the kidneys, CAIs inhibit the carbonic anhydrase enzyme located in the proximal convoluted tubule. These medications increase the amount of bicarbonate, sodium, and water being excreted in the urine. Since CAIs decrease bicarbonate reabsorption, more bicarbonate remains in the urine, resulting in urine alkalinization. Of note, the alkaline urine predisposes patients to forming calcium phosphate renal stones. In contrast, serum bicarbonate concentration decreases, resulting in metabolic acidosis.    

Patients taking CAIs will also develop hypokalemia. This is since CAIs cause increased amounts of urine sodium to reach the collecting duct, where more sodium leads to more potassium excretion into the urine. In addition, patients can develop hyperchloremia since the body compensates for reduced serum bicarbonate levels by releasing chloride from the cells into the blood.  

At high doses, patients may develop neurological side effects such as drowsiness and paresthesias.  

Lastly, CAIs are contraindicated in patients with liver cirrhosis since individuals with liver damage have difficulty removing ammonia from the blood. CAIs further decrease urinary excretion of ammonia, potentially causing hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication prevents bicarbonate reabsorption from the urine. This results in a low serum bicarbonate level and high urine pH, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. 
✅  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide) increase urine bicarbonate excretion. This causes serum bicarbonate to decrease and urine pH to increase, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. However, this medication class would also cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑ ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. Moreover, the medication would cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate recurrent throbbing headaches for six months. The headache occurs over the left side of his head and is associated with nausea, photophobia, and vomiting. The headache is often preceded by a tingling sensation in the right arm and face. The pain improves with resting in a dark, quiet room. Past medical history is significant for a previous suicide attempt, major depressive disorder, and asthma, for which he occasionally uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient stopped taking his sertraline two months ago. The patient drinks 4-6 glasses of wine every day and does not smoke tobacco or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory evaluation reveals transaminitis. The patient insists on a prescription for dihydroergotamine to manage his headache. Which of the following is a contraindication to the administration of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache preceded by an aura and associated with photophobia, nausea, and vomiting. Together, these findings are consistent with migraine with aura. Ergot alkaloids are metabolized in the liver and are contraindicated in patients with abnormal liver function.

Ergot alkaloids such as ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are agonists at 5-HT serotonin receptors.  Ergotamine is a mainstay of treatment for acute migraine attacks and is often combined with caffeine. Side effects of this medication include nausea and vomiting, coronary artery vasospasm,/or hypertension, and leg weakness and muscle pain. Ergots are contraindicated during pregnancy as they stimulate uterine smooth muscle contraction, leading to premature labor in pregnant women.

Intoxication with ergot alkaloids can lead to ergotism, which manifests with spasms, seizures, psychiatric and gastrointestinal symptoms, and gangrene of the hands and feet secondary to vasoconstriction.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of suicide attempts:
Incorrect: Ergot alkaloids have not been shown to increase the risk of suicide attempts.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.  
❌ Frequent alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Ergot alkaloids are not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction. Alcohol consumption is not a contraindication to this medication.  
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Although ergot alkaloids can cause uterine smooth muscle contraction, they do not affect the smooth muscles of the trachea and bronchi. Asthma is not a contraindication of this medication.  
❌ History of sertraline consumption:
Incorrect: Ergot alkaloids should be avoided in patients consuming serotonergic medications such as sertraline due to the risk of developing serotonin syndrome. This patient stopped taking sertraline two months ago.

questions.text: A 13-year-girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due a recent episode of unresponsiveness. The parent states the patient was playing in the yard 30 minutes ago when she started complaining of an abnormal sensation in her chest. This complaint was followed by repetitive fidgeting of the right hand, accompanied by blank staring and unresponsiveness that lasted for about a minute, after which the patient lost consciousness. She has not had any previous similar episodes. Past medical history is significant for a viral infection last month, for which the patient was hospitalized and treated with an intravenous medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears tired but is responsive. The patient’s speech is incomprehensible. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely involved in this patient’s episode?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely had complex focal seizure arising from the temporal lobe. Abnormal discharges in this area are typically preceded by an aura (e.g. rising sensation in epigastrium, smelling burning rubber) followed by blank staring, automatisms and post-ictal loss of consciousness, all of which are seen in this patient. Her history of a viral infection was most likely herpes encephalitis, which may have caused necrosis and subsequent scarring in the temporal lobe.  

Focal seizures are defined as seizures originating in a single cerebral hemisphere. These are usually preceded by aura, depending on the area involved in abnormal discharges, and can be subdivided into:  

  •  Simple focal seizures (also called focal seizures with retained awareness): Patients return immediately to their pre-event baseline without losing consciousness. The symptoms depend on the area of the brain that is involved, ranging from motor (frontal lobe), auditory/olfactory (temporal lobe), visual (occipital lobe), or sensory (parietal lobe). 
  •  Complex focal seizures (also called focal seizures with impaired awareness): Patients become unresponsive (blank staring) and often exhibit automatisms (e.g. lip smacking, hand fidgeting, eye blinking), along with localizing symptoms, followed by brief loss of consciousness. 


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe focal seizures are often characterized by hypermotor tonic episodes and automatisms, such as leg bicycling or pelvic thrusting (sexual automatism) and/or vocalization during the episode. Fear and anxiety can occur as auras, but rising epigastric sensation and fidgeting are atypical.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Focal seizures arising from the parietal lobe are an uncommon occurrence and do not exhibit any distinguishing clinical features. Some studies have found that somatosensory auras can occur, followed by contralateral sensory disturbances. Common underlying pathologies include tumor, stroke, vascular malformation or nonspecific gliosis.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Occipital lobe epilepsy is uncommon. Although it can cause focal seizures with impairment of consciousness, patients usually experience a prodrome of visual auras (flashing or colored lights) or visual distortions (metamorphopsia, micropsia). Postictal blindness can occur.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The cerebellum is mainly involved in balance and coordination. Although temporal lobe epilepsy is associated with cerebellar atrophy in the long-term, this phenomenon usually presents with ataxia, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, she has not had any previous similar episodes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after he fell to the ground and started shaking uncontrollably. According to his parents, while the boy was playing, his body suddenly stiffened, and he fell to the ground and started shaking. The episode lasted approximately one minute, after which the patient briefly lost consciousness. The parents state he regained consciousness within a minute but seemed confused and disoriented. The patient has been experiencing a fever, sore throat and runny nose for the past two days. The symptoms were improving with acetaminophen until today, when he developed high-grade fever and chills. Medical history is noncontributory, and the patient has been achieving developmental milestones appropriately. The patient’s temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg. The child is comfortably playing with a toy and does not appear to be in distress. Physical examination shows an erythematous pharynx without exudate or vesicles. There is no nuchal rigidity or photophobia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of generalized tonic-clonic activity and high-grade fever (most likely due to viral upper respiratory infection) are consistent with the diagnosis of febrile seizure. Occurring in up to 3% of children between six months and six years of age, febrile seizure is the most common neurologic disorder in this age group. It is defined as a convulsive episode associated with elevated body temperature in the absence of central nervous system (CNS) infection, metabolic abnormality or a history of afebrile seizure. It can be:

 


Maximum height of fever and previous history of febrile seizure are important determinants of risk of having a febrile seizure. Viral upper respiratory infection (as seen in this patient with sore throat and runny nose) is the most common culprit. The diagnosis of febrile seizure is clinical, and further neurologic evaluation is not necessary unless there are findings concerning a secondary cause of seizure (metabolic abnormality, meningitis, encephalitis). Generally, reassurance, treatment with acetaminophen as needed, and appropriate follow up is all that is necessary for management.  

Option Analysis

❌ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Incorrect: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy manifests as involuntary jerking movements involving bilateral extremities, and consciousness is preserved during and after the episode. Episodes generally occur in the morning. However, this patient with fever and no history of similar episodes is more likely to have had a febrile seizure.  
✅ Febrile seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Febrile status epilepticus:
Incorrect: Febrile status epilepticus is diagnosed when there is a continuous seizure activity of ≥30 minutes. It is a neurological emergency. This patient’s seizure activity lasted for only a minute, and the patient has fully regained consciousness.  
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis is unlikely in this patient with no nuchal rigidity or photophobia. Moreover, CNS infections usually cause altered consciousness or petechial rashes, none of which are observed in this patient currently playing comfortably.  
❌ Complex partial seizure:
Incorrect: In complex partial seizure, only one cerebral hemisphere is involved initially, causing symptoms on the contralateral side ranging from motor, sensory, autonomic to psychic. It is accompanied by loss of consciousness and postictal confusion or drowsiness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a simple febrile seizure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to an episode of jerky movements that involved stiffening and twitching all over her body. According to the partner, the episode started 30 minutes ago while the patient was working on her laptop, and it lasted approximately one minute. The patient lost consciousness after the episode for approximately 5 minutes. The patient has recently been under significant stress working on a company presentation. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory, and the patient has not had any previous similar episodes. She takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows a bite mark on the left side of the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s generalized jerky movements lasting less than 5 minutes, accompanied by loss of consciousness and postictal state are consistent with a diagnosis of generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS).   

Seizures are defined as sudden, uncontrolled excessive synchronous electrical disturbance in the brain that can be focal (affecting a single area of the brain) or generalized (involving both the hemispheres). GTCS is the most common type of generalized seizures. It manifests as a generalized stiffness of muscles (tonic phase) that is followed by jerking and twitching (clonic phase). Patients tend to lose consciousness during the episode, which remains for a few minutes following cessation of the episode; this sequence is then followed by a gradual regaining of consciousness. The episode is usually accompanied by tongue biting (as seen in this patient), urinary and/or fecal incontinence, and amnesia of the event, but these symptoms are not required for the diagnosis. Certain triggers or precipitants tend to lower seizure threshold; common triggers include, but are not limited to, strong emotions, flashing lights, fever, stress and lack of sleep.  

It is important to note that one seizure episode does not mean the patient has epilepsy. The diagnosis of epilepsy requires a history of at least two unprovoked seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart.   




Option Analysis

✅ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vasovagal syncope:
Incorrect: Although emotional or orthostatic stress can be an inciting event for a vasovagal syncope in young individuals, syncope is not followed by the confusion, and the patient usually recalls a prodrome of pallor, dizziness, nausea or diaphoresis.  
❌ Epilepsy:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of epilepsy requires a history of at least two unprovoked (or reflex) seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart. This patient who has not had any previous similar episodes could not be diagnosed with epilepsy yet.  
❌ Status epilepticus:
Incorrect: Status epilepticus is diagnosed when there is a continuous seizure activity of ≥5 minutes or ≥2 discrete seizures between which there is incomplete recovery of consciousness. It is a neurological emergency. This patient had a single seizure lasting only 1 minute and subsequently regained consciousness.  
❌ Psychogenic non-epileptic seizure:
Incorrect: PNES is derived from psychological underpinnings. The condition tends to occur in front of witnesses and in stressful situations. Its duration is usually longer than 2 minutes, and vocalization is observed during the episode. Moreover, tongue bite and postictal confusion are not usually seen.
